texts.definition: The initial phase in games with clear gameplay phases.
markups: <style="Definition">The initial phase in games with clear gameplay phases.</style>
Some games have phases of gameplay time when different goals and actions are in focus. The <style="CurrentLink">Startgame</style> is the first of these phases in the games that have them.

The opening moves in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Board%20Games">Board Games</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Chess">Chess</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Go">Go</link></style> have been studied in great detail and are classical examples of <style="CurrentLink">Startgame</style> analyses.

Game instances in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Master%20of%20Orion">Master of Orion</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Civilization%20(video%20game)%20series">Civilization series</link></style> start with distinct phases were players need to explore their immediate surroundings and start planning where to place their first outposts.

In the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Starcraft%20series">Starcraft series</link></style> the <style="CurrentLink">Startgame</style> is typically called "Opening". With more symmetrical maps, the first phase in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/League%20of%20Legends">League of Legends</link></style> is called "Laning" and relates to which lanes to the enemies base the players should focus on. This lane-centered opening of game instances is also found in the game's predecessor <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Defense%20of%20the%20Ancients">Defense of the Ancients</link></style>.

The design of <style="CurrentLink">Startgame</style> phases depends much on the design vision for how the game should start and what other phases should exist. In general, only a few actions and goals are available and players typically have what is functionally temporary <style="Link"><link="private-game-spaces">Private Game Spaces</link></style> (In <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Master%20of%20Orion">Master of Orion</link></style>. The <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Civilization%20(video%20game)%20series">Civilization series</link></style>

Examples of <style="CurrentLink">Startgame</style> phases include <style="Link"><link="game-world-exploration">Game World Exploration</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="laning">Laning</link></style>; <style="Link"><link="expansion">Expansion</link></style> may also be a <style="CurrentLink">Startgame</style> phase if <style="Link"><link="game-world-exploration">Game World Exploration</link></style> is not present. The design of any phase which is intended to be the <style="CurrentLink">Startgame</style> phase typically needs to consider a couple of patterns that can cause problems. <style="Link"><link="asymmetric-starting-conditions">Asymmetric Starting Conditions</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="first-player-advantages">First Player Advantages</link></style> may unbalance the game while <style="Link"><link="late-arriving-players">Late Arriving Players</link></style> may cause delays or exclude these players unless the rules support their inclusion.

As a corollary to designing a <style="CurrentLink">Startgame</style> phase in a game, the game needs other phases. A "classical" structure from <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Board%20Games">Board Games</link></style> is to continue to a more complex <style="Link"><link="middlegame">Middlegame</link></style> and then a decisive <style="Link"><link="endgame">Endgame</link></style>.

Games with clear and known <style="CurrentLink">Startgame</style> phases can encourage <style="Link"><link="stimulated-planning">Stimulated Planning</link></style> and development of <style="Link"><link="strategic-knowledge">Strategic Knowledge</link></style> regarding different starting strategies. This means that <style="CurrentLink">Startgame</style> phases support <style="Link"><link="strategic-planning">Strategic Planning</link></style> rather than <style="Link"><link="tactical-planning">Tactical Planning</link></style> in most cases since plans do not have to depend too much on the specific game state of a game instance (due to the limited variation and common patterns which define the <style="CurrentLink">Startgame</style>). Since <style="CurrentLink">Startgame</style> phases tend to have relatively low complexity and available actions, they can support <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Smooth%20Learning%20Curves">Smooth Learning Curves</link></style>.
